IK.floatIK

Class AbstractArmature

  • java.lang.Object
    • IK.floatIK.AbstractArmature
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Saveable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Armature

    public abstract class AbstractArmature
extends java.lang.Object
implements Saveable
    An Armature is a hierarchical collection of Bones. Bones must be descendants of an Armature in order for the IKSolver to run on them.
    Author:
    Eron Gjoni

      • AbstractArmature

        public AbstractArmature(AbstractAxes inputOrigin,
                        java.lang.String name)
        Initialize an Armature with a default root bone matching the given parameters.. The rootBone's length will be 1.
        Parameters:
        inputOrigin - Desired location and orientation of the rootBone.
        name - A human readable name for this armature

      • setDefaultIterations

        public void setDefaultIterations(int iter)
        The default number of iterations to run over this armature whenever IKSolver() is called. The higher this value, the more likely the Armature is to have converged on a solution when by the time it returns. However, it will take longer to return (linear cost)
        Parameters:
        iter -

      • setDefaultDampening

        public void setDefaultDampening(float damp)
        The default maximum number of radians a bone is allowed to rotate per solver iteration. The lower this value, the more natural the pose results. However, this will the number of iterations the solver requires to converge. !!THIS IS AN EXPENSIVE OPERATION. This updates the entire armature's cache of precomputed quadrance angles. The cache makes things faster in general, but if you need to dynamically change the dampening during a call to IKSolver, use the IKSolver(bone, dampening, iterations, stabilizationPasses) function, which clamps rotations on the fly.
        Parameters:
        damp -

      • getRootBone

        the rootBone of this armature.

      • updateArmatureSegments

        public void updateArmatureSegments()
        this method should be called whenever a bone in this armature has been pinned or unpinned. for the most part, the abstract classes call this when necessary. But if you are extending classes more than you would reasonably expect this library to reasonably expect and getting weird results, you might try calling this method after making any substantial structural changes to the armature.

      • refreshArmaturePins

        public void refreshArmaturePins()
        If you have created some sort of save / load system for your armatures which might make it difficult to notify the armature when a pin has been enabled on a bone, you can call this function after all bones and pins have been instantiated and associated with one another to index all of the pins on the armature.

      • IKSolver

        public void IKSolver(AbstractBone bone)
        automatically solves the IK system of this armature from the given bone using the armature's default IK parameters. You can specify these using the setDefaultIterations() setDefaultIKType() and setDefaultDampening() methods. The library comes with some defaults already set, so you can more or less use this method out of the box if you're just testing things out.
        Parameters:
        bone -

      • IKSolver

        public void IKSolver(AbstractBone bone,
                     float dampening,
                     int iterations,
                     int stabilizingPasses)
        automatically solves the IK system of this armature from the given bone using the given parameters.
        Parameters:
        bone -
        dampening - dampening angle in radians. Set this to -1 if you want to use the armature's default.
        iterations - number of iterations to run. Set this to -1 if you want to use the armature's default.
        stabilizingPasses - number of stabilization passes to run. Set this to -1 if you want to use the armature's default.

      • setDefaultStabilizingPassCount

        public void setDefaultStabilizingPassCount(int passCount)
        The solver tends to be quite stable whenever a pose is reachable (or unreachable but without excessive contortion). However, in cases of extreme unreachability (due to excessive contortion on orientation constraints), the solution might fail to stabilize, resulting in an undulating motion. Setting this parameter to "1" will prevent such undulations, with a negligible cost to performance. Setting this parameter to a value higher than 1 will offer minor benefits in pose quality in situations that would otherwise be prone to instability, however, it will do so at a significant performance cost. You're encourage to experiment with this parameter as per your use case, but you may find the following guiding principles helpful:
        • If your armature doesn't have any constraints, then leave this parameter set to 0.
        • If your armature doesn't make use of orientation aware pins (x,y,and,z direction pin priorities are set to 0) the leave this parameter set to 0.
        • If your armature makes use of orientation aware pins and orientation constraints, then set this parameter to 1
        • If your armature makes use of orientation aware pins and orientation constraints, but speed is of the highest possible priority, then set this parameter to 0
        Parameters:
        passCount -
